On 07.06.2009, at 21:17, Will Hartung wrote:

> It seems to me that, whatever acronym you want to use, the "Hypermedia
> Engine" is basically the concept that resources should include not
> just their actual data, but representations of State applicable state
> changes for that resource.

I disagree. What's changing is not (or at least doesn't have to be)  
the state of the resource, but the state of the application. When my  
browser displays an HTML page to me, the application state is "user  
views page X". There might be links and forms included that enable me  
and the browser to change this application state to "user views page  
Y" or "user edits resource Z".

Stefan
